subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes	com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: ... Traditional orthography: that is, not only the use of Latin letters, but the use of them in the traditional way exemplified in this paragraph. (T.O. has
messageBody:
cossyrosario scripsit:

> What is T.O.? Traditional Orthodox? (equivalent to Latin letters?)

Traditional orthography: that is, not only the use of Latin letters,
but the use of them in the traditional way exemplified in this paragraph.
(T.O. has slight national variations, of course.)

This paragraph, on the other hand, is not in T.O., even though it uses
Latin letters; it is in Regularized Inglish, a modest spelling repair
developed by Axel Wijk in the 1950s. As you can see, it is aulmoste the
same as T.O., but lacks the highly irregular spellings. (The version
I employ here is not exactly the same as Wijk's; I doo not use aa, dh,
or z insted of s.)

--
What is the sound of Perl? Is it not the John Cowan
sound of a [Ww]all that people have stopped cowan@...
banging their head against? --Larry http://www.ccil.org/~cowan

cossyrosario scripsit:

> What is T.O.?  Traditional Orthodox? (equivalent to Latin letters?)

Traditional orthography: that is, not only the use of Latin letters,
but the use of them in the traditional way exemplified in this paragraph.
(T.O. has slight national variations, of course.)

This paragraph, on the other hand, is not in T.O., even though it uses
Latin letters; it is in Regularized Inglish, a modest spelling repair
developed by Axel Wijk in the 1950s.  As you can see, it is aulmoste the
same as T.O., but lacks the highly irregular spellings.  (The version
I employ here is not exactly the same as Wijk's; I doo not use aa, dh,
or z insted of s.)

--
